comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I had to look it up - The Australasian United Steam Navigation Company Limited . Complicated full history of the company - espace.library.uq.edu.au/eserv/UQ:213629/s18378366_1954_5... This (new) wharf was to the south of Erskine Street, and shows on this 1905 interactive bird's-eye map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f115-sd&rgn=0.4... It seems that almost EVERY building in this photo has since been replaced. I can (only just) recognize the terraces on the north side of Erskine Street. Any others? From the ship at right, I think ca.1905 - 1910 ?

comment.author: 65594010@N03
comment._content: Parsons Starch factory in background. Internet search has a few details about the company in the first decade of 20th Century and mentioned that the company had used White Australia in it's promotions with trade mark registered 1903.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: My great grandfather worked there in 1927!!! I can't see any of the pubs on Day Street ... so I'm almost useless :D - edit ... i found a pub!

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It is market street at the top right corner  and you can see the end of the roof of the QVB

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content:
I think looking at the buildings that are there that this must be post 1910 as the Balmain Ferry Hotel was definitely still there in 1910 but I think was demolished at a later date. I never did that much research on it but there is an image at City of Sydney Archives of it. (sorry it's very cool image from c1907 but can't find a way to link it).

I will try to find a destruction date tomorrow in Trove

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: ah here we are here is the image: www.photosau.com.au/cos/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=... and SLNSW has another image of a Balmain Ferry Hotel which must be a later building after the streets in the area were reconfigured - you can see the difference. acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=220384 SLNSW date this as c1900 but I doubt it as in 1910 the Balmain Ferry Hotel Building was a rectangular building as shown in the first image and the building looks later than 1900 to me. So we need to look at newspapers to see if there's any more information about when the new one was built I guess!
